title: - Knowledge Sharing - Data Access and Analysis Library
text:
Technology Exploration
Quarto: A versatile publishing tool


Why choose Quarto?

Open Source, actively developed and maintained by Posit Community.
Familiar Syntax & Workflow for Markdown Users.
Multilingual, support for R, Python, Javascript, and Julia…
Enables reproducible code, rich outputs, and seamless format conversion.

Learn More here

title: - Knowledge Sharing - Data Access and Analysis Library
text:
Technology Exploration
Recap of Quarto Features




Quarto
RMarkdown




Supports Python, R, Julia, and Observable.
Primarily uses R for dynamic content.


Offers a wider range of publishing options, including articles, presentations, dashboards, websites, blogs, and books in HTML, PDF, MS Word, ePub, and more.
Limited publishing format: HTML, PDF, and MS Word.


Support a variety of authoring tools like VS Code, RStudio, Jupyter Lab, any text editor, and a visual markdown editor.
Typically uses RStudio as its primary authoring environment.


Facilitates advanced interactivity with Jupyter Widgets, htmlwidgets for R, Observable JS, and Shiny. Quarto extensions simplifies the usage.
Offers interactivity but require additional complicated setup.

title: - Knowledge Sharing - Data Access and Analysis Library
text:
Technology Exploration
Quarto Markdown (.qmd) Examples

---
title: "Quarto Document Example with Labeled Code"
author: "John Smith"
date: "2025-02-15"
format: html
---
# Introduction
This document demonstrates Quarto’s R code chunk.

## Basic Calculation Example
This section calculates the mean of a vector.
The code chunk below is labeled as `calculate_mean` for easier reference.

` ` `{r calculate_mean}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
# This chunk calculates the mean of a vector of numbers
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
mean_value <- mean(numbers)
mean_value
` ` `

title: - Knowledge Sharing - Data Access and Analysis Library
text:
Technology Exploration
Control how your code runs: Execution Options


warning=FALSE: Suppresses warnings.
include=FALSE: Hides code and output but runs the code.
echo=FALSE: Hides code but shows output, useful for report-style documents.
eval=FALSE:Do not run the code. (some code may need special setup or prompts for credentials)

` ` `{r warning=FALSE}

OR

` ` `{r}
#| warning: false

` ` `

Check here for more options.

title: Knowledge sharing: Data access and analysis library
text: Literate programming, introduced by Donald Knuth, is a methodology that intertwines code with human-readable explanations, fostering better knowledge sharing and comprehension. In data access, processing, and analysis pipelines, literate programming enables analysts, engineers, and researchers to document and share their work transparently. Clear documentation ensures that complex data transformations, model evaluations, and analytical decisions are easily understood and reproducible.

title: Knowledge sharing: Data access and analysis library
text: Literate programming, introduced by Donald Knuth, is a methodology that intertwines code with human-readable explanations, fostering better knowledge sharing and comprehension. In data access, processing, and analysis pipelines, literate programming enables analysts, engineers, and researchers to document and share their work transparently. Clear documentation ensures that complex data transformations, model evaluations, and analytical decisions are easily understood and reproducible.

title: Knowledge sharing: Data access and analysis library
text:
Modern literate programming using Quarto
Quarto is a modern, open-source publishing system that combines the power of R, Python, and Markdown to create dynamic documents, reports, presentations, and websites. It turns source code, text, and visuals into polished, shareable outputs. It is designed for seamless collaboration and reproducibility, making it an ideal tool for knowledge sharing amongst IDM data scientists, researchers, and developers.
Rich Quarto documents and notebooks also offer powerful potential for fine-tuning LLMs by integrating structured metadata, natural language explanations, and executable code. Leveraging front matter (YAML metadata) and code sections, we can extract clear, labeled training data, where explanations act as prompts and code as completions, advancing literate programming to a new level in the LLM era.

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text: What is Codespace

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text: Seamless cloud development

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text:
Advantages


Connect from anywhere (with internet access)
Use a preconfigured development environment (Reproducibility)
Scale compute resources as needed
Pair programming with a teammate (through VSCode live share)
Fast deploy and host your application in the early stage for peer review and demo
Seamless GitHub Integration

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text:
Considerations


Must connect to the internet
Limited IDE choices (VSCode, JetBrains)
Cost for long term usage, see Free usage and Billing
No GA for GPU Support
Persistence and Storage Challenges

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text:
How to use Codespace


Create a new Codespace 
Use default configuration
Manage your Codespace

title: Introduction of Github Codespace
text:
Advanced Features


Custom configurations
Prebuild can accelerate the start time of your Codespace
Deep Link can share your Codespace configuration with others
Port Forwarding can share your application to public or private within organization
Work Offline with VSCode

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
text:
How do you install quarto?

Run install.packages(“quarto”)
Download and install Quarto from quarto.org
It is installed with Rstudio
Run pip install quarto


You can find the installation instructions here Back to Home Page

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
section: Which Quarto command is used to render a document to HTML?
text:
Which Quarto command is used to render a document to HTML?

quarto preview
quarto render
quarto build
quarto export


You can use quarto –help or quarto help to see the available command options. Back to Home Page

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
section: Which command checks if Quarto is installed correctly?
text:
Which command checks if Quarto is installed correctly?

quarto –version
quarto –validate
Both quarto –version and quarto check
quarto status


Check this site for more information on Trouble shooting Back to Home Page

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
section: How do you add a Python code chunk in a Quarto document?

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
section: What is the purpose of Quarto extensions?
text:
What is the purpose of Quarto extensions?

To add support for new programming languages
To enhance functionality with templates, themes, and custom formats
To debug code
To install user interface


Check this site for more information on Extensions Back to Home Page

title: Test your knowledge about quarto!
section: How to prevent execution for a specific R code chunk in Quarto?
text:
How to prevent execution for a specific R code chunk in Quarto?

Use #| echo: FALSE
Use #| eval: FALSE
Use #| include: FALSE
Use #| cache: TRUE


Check this site for more information on Code execution options Back to Home Page
